header.title: The 21 Spells of Domesius
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Grimoire Tradition, Practical Magic

central_thesis: The text presents a collection of 21 'High Magic' spells attributed to Domesius, characterized by their powerful nature and an inclination towards the 'dark side'. It serves as a practical manual detailing specific rituals, invocations, and material components for various magical operations, ranging from gaining allies and wealth to protection, banishing fear, and communing with spirits.

structure_content.summary: A spell to secure an ally, requiring a bodily sample from the target, symbolic inscription, and a specific invocation performed at midnight during a waxing moon with two candles. The charged packet is then concealed.

A decision-making spell using a solitary candle and seven pieces of paper, each representing a choice. The papers are laid in a circle, the candle rotated seven times clockwise, and the choice moving furthest when the candle is extinguished by breath is indicated as the correct path.
An invocation performed at sunrise with a cup of fresh water, designed to uplift spirits, banish burdens, and instill a will to win. The ritual concludes with drinking the water.

structure_content.chapter_title: To Gain the Heart of Another
structure_content.summary: A spell to win the affection of a desired person, involving a small object touched by the target, their name and the practitioner's name written on cloth, and two candles. An incantation is recited, and the object is kept after one candle naturally burns out.

A ritual to expel 'Spirits of Fear' performed at sunrise on the twelfth day of the month. It involves spreading a mixture of thyme, rosemary, and ginger on a white cloth and reciting an invocation. The cloth is then shaken clean outdoors and washed.

A protective spell against evil, requiring a thorough cleansing bath after midnight and a dawn ritual. The practitioner faces south in a well-lit room, invoking 'Baëll, king of the evil horde' in all four directions, concluding with a specific invocation facing east, and turning south to seal the spell.

A spell to exert pressure upon enemies, cast at midnight on a waning moon. Three candles form a triangle, a fourth is held. The names of enemies are spoken, and an invocation for retribution is recited while focusing on the candle flame. The held candle is extinguished after passing the hand over its flame, followed by the others clockwise.
A nightly incantation recited aloud before sleep to prevent unwanted visitors or negative influences from entering the dreaming mind, promoting peaceful rest and quiet dreams.

A spell for uncovering hidden knowledge, involving a prepared oak twig, a solitary candle, and a piece of paper. The twig's end is charred, knowledge desired is written on the paper with it, the paper is rolled and sealed with wax, then buried with the twig, and rainwater poured over the spot.

A spell to conceal an object or person, performed at midnight. The caster holds a solitary candle and sprinkles salt and rosemary over the target, then recites an invocation to spirits of darkness for protection and invisibility from seekers.

An incantation for guiding the spirit of a deceased loved one, performed at dawn after a death. Seven candles are arranged directionally, and an invocation is spoken from the southern end, asking guides to lead the departed to a place of peace and reward. Candles burn for at least an hour.

A spell for moving unnoticed or traveling undetected, requiring two candles and a smooth stone. Incantations are recited while extinguishing candles, then a final invocation is spoken while holding the stone in total darkness, asking spirits to cloak the practitioner in shadows.

A spell to break the ties of an 'unmatched or endangered pair,' performed at midday on a Wednesday. It involves a single candle, a length of natural twine representing the pair, and rainwater. An incantation is recited, the twine is burned in two by the flame and quenched in rainwater, then buried in separate locations with half the water each. The candle must burn until fully consumed.

An invocation to the 'Spirits of the Seven Winds' to strengthen psychic powers. Performed outdoors on a waxing moon, the practitioner stands with arms extended, rotating clockwise while reciting the invocation for knowledge, wisdom, truth, and fortitude.

A spell for attracting wealth, performed at sunset. A shallow hole is dug in fresh earth, into which an oak leaf, three new coins, a strand of the practitioner's hair, and a pinch of salt are placed in order, followed by an invocation. The hole is refilled with dirt and watered with rainwater for three days.

A ritual to wash away bad memories and pain using two bowls of river water and a smooth river stone. A solitary candle is lit, and incantations are recited while passing the stone through the flame and rubbing it in the left bowl, then swirling it in the right. The dried stone is placed under the pillow nightly until memories fade.

A spell to bring good fortune, cast near midnight on a full moon. It involves three fresh oak leaves, a dried eggshell, a hen's egg-sized stone, two candles, and a cloth pouch. The eggshell is ground, sprinkled over the leaves, and with the stone, placed in the pouch after an invocation. The pouch is then sealed with three knots and kept as a charm.

A spell to fortify oneself against a dangerous lover, cast at midnight on a full moon. A sharp or jagged stone/jewel is placed in the center of four lit candles, arranged directionally. An invocation to 'Bileth of the Orders of Powers' is recited to make the heart as stone. The candles are extinguished, and the stone is carried for protection.

An invocation for wants and wishes. An empty cup is placed on a table surrounded by three candles in a triangle. A small amount of water is poured, and while imagining the wish, an invocation is recited. The water is drunk, candles extinguished, and a final ending phrase is spoken for patience and freedom from greed.

A spell to enhance learning and rapidly acquire knowledge, cast outdoors on the third night of the waxing moon. Three equal-length wooden sticks form a triangle on the ground, with the practitioner's index fingers pointing into the center while reciting an invocation to the 'Stars of heaven' for aid.

structure_content.chapter_title: Incantation for Conjuring the Spirits of the Night
structure_content.summary: A midnight ritual to conjure spirits for communication. Performed in a dark, secluded room with an open window, facing north. The practitioner clears their mind, then recites an invocation to the 'Spirits of the night'. After speaking, eyes are closed to welcome and communicate mentally with the arriving spirits.

key_concepts.definition: Powerful, mystery spells with an inclination toward the 'dark side', requiring experienced practitioners.
The practitioner of magickal arts to whom the discovered writings forming this collection of spells are attributed.
A core ritual component, involving spoken words or chants to call upon spirits, powers, or forces to effect a magical outcome. Often highly poetic and directional.

The principle that objects or actions can influence others due to a mystic connection. This is evident through the use of bodily samples (hair, blood), objects touched by individuals, or physical representations like twine for a pair.

Specific celestial phases (waxing moon, waning moon, full moon) and times of day (midnight, dawn, sunrise, sunset, midday) are crucial for the efficacy of many spells, indicating an astrological or temporal sensitivity.

Direct appeals and commands to specific spiritual entities or forces, such as 'Spirit of the Rising Sun', 'Baëll, king of the evil horde', 'Spirits of the Seven Winds', 'Spirits of the darkness', and 'Bileth of the Orders of Powers'.
The stated legal and commercial classification for the distributed spells, implying they are for novelty or entertainment purposes, as a disclaimer by the publisher.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in 'The 21 Spells of Domesius' is heavily ritualistic, emphasizing precise execution, material components, and specific timings. Operations typically involve the lighting and extinguishing of candles, the manipulation of symbolic objects, and the recitation of invocations. A key operative principle is sympathetic magic, utilizing personal effects (bodily samples, touched objects) or symbolic representations to influence desired outcomes. Directional orientation, lunar phases, and specific times of day are often critical elements of the ritual setup. The practitioner's intent, focus, and adherence to steps are paramount, with warnings regarding potential repercussions for misuse.
tools: Candles (various counts: solitary, two, three, four, seven)
Paper (torn or cut to specific shapes/sizes)
Bodily samples (hair, nail, blood, bodily excretion)
Personal objects (items touched or held by target)
Stones (smooth, jagged, opal-like, hen's egg sized)
rituals: Lighting and extinguishing candles in specific configurations and sequences (solitary, pairs, triangles, directional)
Writing names or symbols on paper or cloth, often with specific tools (charred twig, pen and ink)
Using bodily samples (hair, nail, blood, excretion) or personal objects from targets or self
Reciting invocations and incantations aloud, sometimes with specific gestures (rotating body, hand movements)
Placing objects in specific layouts (circles, triangles, directional arrangements) on altars or the ground
Burying charged items in earth or disposing of them in specific ways (quenching in rainwater)
Using charged water (rainwater, river water) for cleansing, empowerment, or disposal
Focused meditation and visualization of intent before or during ritual operations
Physical cleansing (bathing) prior to certain protective rites

relevant_quotes.text: The 21 Lost Spells of Domesius is a rare collection of powerful, "High Magic", mystery spells with an inclination toward the dark side. It is recommended for experienced practitioners or the adventurous and the publisher and distributor of this collection or any of its parts shall be held harmless against and free from all liabilities.
These spells are distributed as curios only and intended for entertainment.
This collection is based on writings discovered and attributed to a practitioner of the magickal arts known only as Domesius. This is the first time these spells have ever been publicly published.

The intent of this spell is to bring great pressure on your enemies. The spell must be used judiciously so as not to bring unnecessary suffering to the innocent and blameless. If ill-used, the effects of this spell can return upon you and your life turned to misery.
To destroy the ties of an unmatched or endangered pair, is a serious undertaking and all consequent repercussions must carefully be taken under consideration before the casting of this spell.

critical_analysis.relevance: This grimoire is highly relevant for understanding a distinct, modern practical magical system that explicitly acknowledges and leans into 'darker' aspects of magic while providing ethical warnings. It offers insight into the integration of sympathetic magic, precise timing, and direct spirit invocation within a structured, step-by-step ritual framework. Its attribution to a singular, obscure figure 'Domesius' and first-time publication adds a unique historical dimension to contemporary occult studies, bridging traditional grimoire formats with what appears to be a personalized magical praxis.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The book explicitly targets 'experienced practitioners or the adventurous.' This suggests an audience already familiar with occult concepts and practices, capable of discerning the risks and responsibilities associated with 'High Magic' and its 'dark side' inclination, as well as those seeking practical application within similar traditions.
